message.raw:
a (hopefully temporary) fix for bug #610.
This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

This is in the h5_lock module, which is where I was hacking things onto h5py anyway. I've disabled the actual h5_locking for the moment, until I make a few changes to pythonlib to accomodate it, such as BLACS worker processes not holding the file open for minutes at a time while they program a device (I'm looking at you, novatech) when they could easily close the file prior to programming.

Added imports everywhere needed throughout pythonlib

message.raw: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.
message.html: Modified how subprocesses pipe output to parent processes. No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

No longer do parents need to filter the output of the children to see what is stdout and what is stderr and what's something else of interest. Now parents pass in a port when calling the child, and children send their output directly to an OutputBox or similar via zmq push, no filtering step required. Also, since this is using raw zmq sockets, it ought to be faster.

message.raw: Added some re-lookup of values that may have changed since they were last gotten. This was not threadsafe, and may have resulted in previous errors. It shouldn't have crashed lyse, but may have put the analysis loop in an inconsistent state, perhaps failing to report progress on a shot and maybe performing analysis on it twice or something similar.

message.raw:
Removed spinners from routineboxes. They now display a static icon. This is due to a memory leak in gtk spinners. If the memory leak bug gets fixed, we'll put spinners back in.
 The code for making the spinner spin is still there, incrementing an integer that would make the spinner spin, but that column in the liststore is not being used by anything. Its been left in to make it easy to revert this change if the memory leak is fixed.

message.raw:
Worked around a bug where numpy.void types underwent data corruption when being pickled and unpickled.

Discussion of the bug can be found here:
https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/1939

The underlying bug is in numpy and shows no signs of being fixed any time soon, so in the meantime we're converting to our own datatype which has mostly the same functionality.

message.raw: Fixed a bug where two plots would alternate which window they were in if the user didn't call figure() prior to the first one. This change calls figure() prior to calling the user's code so that the current figure is always the same at the beginning of the user's analysis.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug where sometimes new shots would not be analysed until analysis was paused and restarted.
Modified dataframe_utilities so that the dataframe now has columns for 'individual id' and 'generation', which are put there by mise. If these attributes are absent they are ignored.

message.raw:
Didn't have the gtk lock whilst toggling the pause button after a failed analysis. This is likely the cause of an obscure error we got at this point in the program, since toggling a button is not threadsafe.
Hopefully this fixes the problem!
message.html:
Didn't have the gtk lock whilst toggling the pause button after a failed analysis. This is likely the cause of an obscure error we got at this point in the program, since toggling a button is not threadsafe.
Hopefully this fixes the problem!

message.raw:
Lyse no longer uses HTTPRequestHandlers to serve and urllib.urlopen to request data, it now uses subproc_utils.ZMQServers and subproc_utils.zmq_get respectively.
This breaks interaction with BLACS, so I'll be modifying BLACS and runmanager similarly shortly.
message.html:
Lyse no longer uses HTTPRequestHandlers to serve and urllib.urlopen to request data, it now uses subproc_utils.ZMQServers and subproc_utils.zmq_get respectively.
This breaks interaction with BLACS, so I'll be modifying BLACS and runmanager similarly shortly.

message.raw:
lyse.log location is no longer hard-coded.
Fixed bug where lyse could not have files added if analysislib was not installed.
Added methods to Run class (get_globals_raw, get_units and iterable_globals). The latter does not work yet, however, and will probably be added to runmanager instead.

message.raw: Resolves #537 and resolves #542. 'sequence' and 'run time' columns are kept in the DataFrame after creating the MultiIndex. This refs #443, allowing slicing of the DataFrame by run time and sequence, however the sequence identifier is attained by string munging the filepath in lieu of implementation of #443.

message.raw: Made analysis subprocesses actually quit when asked. Made lyse ask for them to quit on shutdown, so that they quit immediately rather than relying on the absence of heartbeats to cause a kill.
message.html: Made analysis subprocesses actually quit when asked. Made lyse ask for them to quit on shutdown, so that they quit immediately rather than relying on the absence of heartbeats to cause a kill.

message.raw:
Fixed a bug with a gtk callback not being removed correctly when an analysis routine is killed or removed. Made analysis routines be removed a little more gently, rather than just killing them. If an analysis routine is actually stuck doing some work, it will remain stuck now and not get killed. But it will die once it finishes doing the work!

Made a start putting some better logging in place. Haven't got that far. Removed OutputBox from main.pyw and OutputInterceptor from analysis_subprocess, they are both now in subproc_utils so I can re-use them elsewhere. See that commit message for more info. I think those two classes are the bee's knees.

Got rid of annoying warnings about h5 non-errors and signal handlers not being connected.

Removed OutputBox from main.pyw and OutputInterceptor from analysis_subprocess, they are both now in subproc_utils so I can re-use them elsewhere. See that commit message for more info. values.message:
Fixed a bug with a gtk callback not being removed correctly when an analysis routine is killed or removed. Made analysis routines be removed a little more gently, rather than just killing them. If an analysis routine is actually stuck doing some work, it will remain stuck now and not get killed. But it will die once it finishes doing the work!

Made a start putting some better logging in place. Haven't got that far. Removed OutputBox from main.pyw and OutputInterceptor from analysis_subprocess, they are both now in subproc_utils so I can re-use them elsewhere. See that commit message for more info. I think those two classes are the bee's knees.

Got rid of annoying warnings about h5 non-errors and signal handlers not being connected.

message.raw:
Fixed two bugs which could cause lyse to crash.
One was when an analysis routine was removed from the routinebox whilst running. This would previously cause lyse to hang. It now counts it as the routine having completed.
Another was when a h5 file was opened which didn't contain some the required attributes and groups. These parts of the dataframe will now be filled with NaNs. In future we should probably not allow these files to be loaded in, since they are runs which did not execute properly. But at least this way lyse doesn't crash and can continue to be run.
message.html:
Fixed two bugs which could cause lyse to crash.
One was when an analysis routine was removed from the routinebox whilst running. This would previously cause lyse to hang. It now counts it as the routine having completed.
Another was when a h5 file was opened which didn't contain some the required attributes and groups. These parts of the dataframe will now be filled with NaNs. In future we should probably not allow these files to be loaded in, since they are runs which did not execute properly. But at least this way lyse doesn't crash and can continue to be run.

Fixed two bugs which could cause lyse to crash.
One was when an analysis routine was removed from the routinebox whilst running. This would previously cause lyse to hang. It now counts it as the routine having completed.
Another was when a h5 file was opened which didn't contain some the required attributes and groups. These parts of the dataframe will now be filled with NaNs. In future we should probably not allow these files to be loaded in, since they are runs which did not execute properly. But at least this way lyse doesn't crash and can continue to be run.

message.raw:
Added a global variable to the lyse module called spinning_top. If it's True, then the script is being run from within lyse (the application). If false then the lyse module is being imported from a script being run outside of the lyse application.

Also have overridden matplotlib.pyplot.show() such that calls to show() are ignored when not running from within the lyse application
message.html:

Also have overridden matplotlib.pyplot.show() such that calls to show() are ignored when not running from within the lyse application

message.raw:
Fixed a bug whereby lyse would not show figures correctly if the user had called pylab.close()
The lyse figure manager now overrides pylab.close as well, so that it can take this into account.
lyse also uses its own figure manager to introspect figures now, rather than just calling pylab.figure(i) and looking at what it gets

lyse also uses its own figure manager to introspect figures now, rather than just calling pylab.figure(i) and looking at what it gets

message.raw:
Added a figure manager which overrides matplotlib.pyplot.figure and pylab.figure.
If imported prior to either of these, it will override the figure() function and allow arbitrary labels for figures, as well as returning the first empty figure whenever the figure() function is called with no arguments. This resolves #488.
message.html:
Added a figure manager which overrides matplotlib.pyplot.figure and pylab.figure.
If imported prior to either of these, it will override the figure() function and allow arbitrary labels for figures, as well as returning the first empty figure whenever the figure() function is called with no arguments. This resolves #488.

message.raw: Fixed bug where matplotlib plots would freeze up shortly after being displayed. Turns out you can't create windows in threads other than the main thread. So now the window creation happens in a callback triggered with a gobject.idle_add()

message.raw: Reverted previous change to lyse. Instead exended the interface provided by subproc_utils to allow feedback so that a server can send to its own listener (lyse uses this to shut down the listener thread in the event that the child process dies, otherwise it would block forever).
message.html: Reverted previous change to lyse. Instead exended the interface provided by subproc_utils to allow feedback so that a server can send to its own listener (lyse uses this to shut down the listener thread in the event that the child process dies, otherwise it would block forever).
